comments.commentBody: This was soooogood.  BUT, I did change it up in that I browned that lamb, and kept back the potatoes until toward the end, so that they had identity.  Also had small turnips which I kept intact.  You have to honor your ingredients in a stew.

my mom was (or still is) one of the "bobby sox"-ers that used to follow The Voice around.  as a teen listening to led zeppelin i had no time for frank.  probably 20 years later i was listening to some old-time radio station and they played this song.  perhaps i was in an odd mood at the time but the song resonated with me.  i started to listen to The Voice more and more.  he has a way of making the song his own and making you a part of the song.  it's an experience.  and there is nobody out there today who can win like frank - nobody.

Artie, my opinions are my own, and while I have no doubt that what you say about the opera singers is correct, it's neither here nor there as far as I'm concerned -- I still don't like the guy.

As to the Goldberg Variations and Art of the Fugue, I'm afraid I don't see why, as someone who reveres Bach above all composers, I can't mention his works -- particularly when I mentioned them in response to an asinine comment that implied that I had a bad love life because I don't like Sinatra. I don't think I know any woman my age who's a Sinatra fan, and in my experience women love the music I play -- except for the Sex Pistols, that didn't go over too well, LOL.
Well written. Well expressed. Well capturing 'the man and his music.' Kudos Stephen Holden.

In the summer of 1964 when I was seventeen and living in New York, the Forest Hills Tennis Stadium was a big concert venue. Because my father worked there as a ticket taker, I was able to get in to see The Beatles, Barbra Streisand, Judy Garland and Frank Sinatra. I was a big Streisand fan and it was a dream come true to see her live in concert. Judy was about forty minutes late coming on, couldn't remember her lyrics and the talk was she was drunk. As for The Beatles--total pandemonium. And then there was Sinatra. Like Garland, he was of a different generation but I remember his concert the most mainly because of how that packed stadium was just swooning over him. Women screaming, "Frankie..." The night was electric. I wasn't a fan before that concert, but left there knowing I had experienced something very special. Lucky me.

Yeah, well AMPAS decided to give Spike Lee a "career" Oscar this year.  Apparently they feel sheepish about having given him a grand total of one nomination (Best Original Screenplay for Do the Right Thing) in all the years he's been making films.   And they'll go right back to ignoring him starting with Chi-Raq.

Sam, Fitzgerald was a different kind of singer, someone who served the music rather than emoting all over it. This apparently doesn't suit Stephen Holden's tastes, but it seems to me that he was wrong to make a critical claim of inferiority on that basis.

I think that you may be missing the article's point William. The great, great songwriters you mention were already well in the past when Sinatra made his Capitol recordings of the fifties. In rerecording those standards with the breathtaking panache and swing that he did (not to mention the fabulous Nelson Riddle arrangements AND the vastly superior recording technology of the time), he revived those standards for future generations. Moreover, many of them came from long since forgotten stage productions of the twenties and thirties and might not have survived till our day without him -- notwithstanding Ella Fitzgerald's noble and praiseworthy attempts to revive them in her "songbook" albums of the period.

This is a nice tribute, but it goes astray in claiming that no one took the great American songbook seriously before Sinatra sang its songs.  Richard Rogers, Irving Berlin, Harold Arlen, Jerome Kern, Cole Porter, and George Gershwin not taken seriously?  Come on!  Which is not to deny that Sinatra was the greatest single pop vocalist of the century, but in large part because of the quality of the material he had to work with.  Later singers mentioned in the article, despite their many virtues, recorded genuinely kitschy material (Elvis), or material of little musical (as opposed to ideological, attitudinal and arguably poetic) significance (Dylan). Very few singer-songwriters after 1960 have risen to the levels of musical skill shown by the specialist songwriters listed here, even though the latter worked in a very restricted idiom.  And sure, Nelson Riddle deserves our utmost respect, but again, look at what he had to work with.

Was it the voice, the people that wrote the songs he sang, or the obviously talented musicians that backed his singing? An American Original and a bit of an American Paradox. I know enough about Sinatra to appreciate the side of him that gave and helped others and do enjoy listening to his recordings. That said, he frequently seems to have sung off-key?

And what would that be? Jail everyone until they can prove their sane?
No, control the mass murder weapons.

His mental status cannot be ignored in assessing the truth or falseness of claims that PP committed atrocities. How many people can look at pictures of Robert L. Dear and conclude that his stated motivations have anything to do with his actions? To seriously assess the validity of his claims -- and I take no position on them -- is absurd. This man clearly is unbalanced, should have been either institutionalized or otherwise closely supervised and probably on medications. He wasn't; and, in Colorado Springs, he could have come by guns in many ways, legal or unlawful. Why is it so politically incorrect to state the obvious that we must pretend that anything PP ever did had anything to do with his murders? That Ted Cruz should be sufficiently supportive of a call to kill abortion doctors that he proudly accepts an endorsement from those who call for such murders is outrageous, and should be used in political ads to discredit his candidacy. But let's not bury the lead: we have possibly millions of deranged people walking about unsupervised in our country, many of them have the potential to become Robert L. Dear, and many have access to guns, legally or otherwise obtained. Something needs to be done about that.

What made Sinatra the greatest pop singer of all time was that, despite the macho bravado and masculine front he presented as his image, he never feared to display--nay, reveal--his innermost feelings in his singing. No one can match the open confession of humanity and mortality that he revealed in his great albums with Axel Stordahl or Nelson Riddle.

Even when his instrument failed him as he got older, his singing endured because he bared his soul almost every time he went onstage.

This is really the essence of his near-universal appeal. There was genuinely very little hype or overstatement in him, simply the honest transformation of personal life into the sound, music, and words of an individual human being.

“The next step is post-trial motions. We intend to pursue them vigorously.” Like shopping around for a more sympathetic judge (he has the power and connections), or a more sympathetic jury (like moving the appeal trial upstate), or a legal loop hole. Anything that will get them both acquitted, or be able to claim a mistrial. Just like Joseph Bruno did. And unfortunately, just like what Shelly Silver is doing right now. That's politics in The Empire State.

Good point.  Glenwood Management, the big real estate and rental apartment empire, cooperated with the prosecution.  Never answered is the question, what was Glenwood doing in the same room with Skelos, time after time, and what favors do companies like Glenwood Management get from their regular meetings with our elected officials, favors the rest of us don't get?

Your pleas for mercy are admirable and becoming. They go against the
strong, bitter tide of these comments and are a strong credit to you
and anyone who shares them. But I say respectfully: these convicts
have gamed the system for years. More, they have shaped it and
prevented the many, many appeals for cleanup and honesty. Their
transgression isn't a one time succumbing to frailty or bad judgment.

You've become more compassionate with age.

They didn't.

Sorry, Sid: No compassion from this corner. How much did these two crooks cost us, the citizens and beleaguered taxpayers of the State of New York? They traded their offices for favors. So how much legislation that was not good for the commonweal (but WAS good for their friends) was enacted into law? And because of these "ill-gotten" laws how many businesses and their jobs did not locate in New York, or expand in New York, or left New York, and how much ultimately got added onto everyone else's tax bill to make up for the breaks given to their friends?
You are right, though, that the crooked businessmen shouldn't get off entirely free. The could have gone to the US Attorney early in the game.

Assets, indeed. What really gets me is that they get to keep their pensions -- just like our crooked former State Comptroller Alan Hevesi who went to jail and the Superintendent of the Roslyn School District Tassone. Meanwhile, there was a story in the paper 2 or 3 years ago about a NYC sanitation man who accepted a $20 gratuity from a grateful homeowner for hauling a big piece of trash and the guy got slammed for violating a dept. regulation. The story said at the time that he lost his job and his pension. Hope the US Attorney can clawback those legislators' pensions!

Sidney: How can you say Silver was a responsible member of the assembly? He is a convicted felon; a thief. The same with Skelos, father and son. There is no "gloating", rather there is praise for the prosecutor and a seemingly-broke system that all to-seldom protects the public from people like this three. As for the businessmen; if they pay bribes for jobs, they too should be prosecuted. Those that succumb to threats and pay, are victims not perpetrators.
There's a lot of us in Greece as well, along with British and Australian ex-pats.
Yeah but you guys have eleven (soon to be twelve I hear) aircraft carrier battle groups, so there's that.  Me, I'll take health care but apparently that is what your electorate wants.

Is a large government giveaway to flows of immigrants around the world really a selling point?

Seriously?

I live only a matter of 100 miles or so from where Mr. Trudeau told the refugees "you are home", but it might as well be a world away. It’s hard not to feel a little envious of Canadians' good fortune to have a leader with Mr. Trudeau's instinct for doing the right thing with confidence and not giving in to fear. Not so long ago, leadership like that would have inspired pride among most people in the United States.

Not so incidentally, the editorial left out a few of Mr. Trudeau’s words that Americans should know about. One of his sentences reads, in full:

“Tonight they step off the plane as refugees, but they walk out of this terminal as permanent residents of Canada, with social insurance numbers, with health cards, and with an opportunity to become full Canadians.”

We not even extend the right to health cards to our own citizens, let alone refugees.
No doubt they will name each other.

There have been many turning points in race relations and justice in America, brought about by brave black people AND brave white people. The job is not finished but never assume that every white person on a jury or wearing a police badge is blinded by prejudice.
Hey commenters, her name is Ms. Ligons, not Liggins.  Get it straight.
To Ms. Ligons and all the "non-grandmothers" who participated in this case, all respect goes to you for standing tall and speaking up.

This is the next level of abuse of police power.  We all know that an officer can kill you in cold blood totally get away with it.  So what is stopping him from rape?  From stealing your money?  It is completely logical to conclude this as well.
I agree.   Ms. Ligons is a hero and deserving of The Medal of Freedom.

While I applaud Ms. Ligons for reporting the crime, the award should go to Kim Davis, the Oklahoma City police officer who investigated the case. Davis took Ms. Ligons's information and ferreted out the other victims who did not report. Without this officer's thorough work, the other assaults would not have come to light and a jury might not have convicted Holtzclaw for any assault.

The Presidential Medal of Freedom goes to individuals who have made "an especially meritorious contribution to the security or national interests of the United States, world peace, cultural or other significant public or private endeavor." Ms. Ligons would be a most appropriate recipient of this award for having brought to light not only what she endured but also what many women, especially women of color, have endured at the hands of the very men who were being paid to protect them. Sadly, this one judicial decision will not end such abuses, but let's hope it acts as a mighty deterrent.
I remember it as being the theme song to Big John and Little Sparky. BTW, Frank was the greatest.
